stem: For each client presentation below, determine the appropriate triage category based on the START triage system.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
08:15 Report from site: Large-scale explosion at chemical plant. Multiple casualties, resources stretched. Need immediate triage guidance.

Client A: 62-year-old male. Ambulatory, multiple superficial lacerations, oriented to time, place, and person. RR 20, HR 90, able to follow commands.

Client B: 45-year-old female. Unresponsive, no respirations after repositioning airway. Obvious head trauma with exposed brain matter.

Client C: 10-year-old male. RR 36 and labored, capillary refill > 2 seconds, unable to obey commands.

Client D: 30-year-old male. Femur fracture with significant bleeding controlled by direct pressure. RR 24, capillary refill < 2 seconds, able to obey commands.

Client E: 78-year-old female. Significant burns over 80% of body, unresponsive.

Requesting immediate direction for triage tagging and evacuation priorities. 

Dr. Ramirez notified.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: No vital sign trends available. Initial assessment values documented in Nurse's Notes.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: Physical exam findings documented in Nurse's Notes.

rows.text: 62-year-old male, ambulatory, superficial lacerations, oriented, RR 20, HR 90, follows commands.
45-year-old female, unresponsive, no respirations after airway repositioning, obvious head trauma.
10-year-old male, RR 36 and labored, capillary refill > 2 seconds, unable to obey commands.
30-year-old male, femur fracture, bleeding controlled, RR 24, capillary refill < 2 seconds, obeys commands.
78-year-old female, significant burns over 80% of body, unresponsive.

rationale.correct: START triage prioritizes rapid assessment and categorization based on immediate life threats. Red (Immediate) indicates life-threatening conditions requiring immediate intervention. Yellow (Delayed) indicates serious but not immediately life-threatening conditions. Green (Minor) indicates minor injuries. Black (Expectant) indicates injuries incompatible with life or requiring extensive resources unlikely to change outcome.
rationale.incorrect: Red (Immediate) is incorrect because these clients do not meet the criteria for immediate life-saving intervention based on START triage. Yellow (Delayed) is incorrect because these clients do not have serious but not immediately life-threatening conditions. Green (Minor) is incorrect because these clients have injuries beyond the scope of minor treatment. Black (Expectant) is incorrect because these clients are not expected to survive given available resources.

answerBreakdown.rationale: The client is ambulatory, alert, and has minor injuries. According to START triage, this client is categorized as Green (Minor) as they can walk and follow commands, indicating non-life-threatening injuries.

answerBreakdown.text: Unresponsive female with head trauma and no respirations after airway repositioning
answerBreakdown.rationale: The client is unresponsive, not breathing even after airway repositioning, and has obvious head trauma. According to START triage, this client is categorized as Black (Expectant) due to the severity of injuries and poor prognosis.

answerBreakdown.text: Child with RR 36 and labored, capillary refill > 2 seconds, unable to obey commands
answerBreakdown.rationale: The child has a respiratory rate >30, capillary refill > 2 seconds, and cannot follow commands. According to START triage, this client is categorized as Red (Immediate), as they require immediate intervention to improve perfusion and oxygenation.

answerBreakdown.text: Male with femur fracture, controlled bleeding, RR 24, capillary refill < 2 seconds, obeys commands
answerBreakdown.rationale: The client has a significant injury (femur fracture) but bleeding is controlled, and vital signs are relatively stable. According to START triage, this client is categorized as Yellow (Delayed) as they require medical attention but not immediately.

The client has extensive burns and is unresponsive. According to START triage, this client is categorized as Black (Expectant) because the burns are so extensive that their survival is unlikely even with intensive medical intervention.

clinicalPearls: START triage is designed for rapid assessment and categorization of victims during a mass casualty incident.
The '30-2-Can Do' mnemonic helps remember the key assessments for START triage: RR > 30, Capillary Refill > 2 seconds, and inability to follow simple commands (Can Do).

questionTrap.trap: Students often confuse Yellow (Delayed) and Red (Immediate) categories, especially when a client has a significant injury but stable vital signs.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the immediate threats to life. Red tagged individuals need treatment within minutes to survive. Yellow tagged clients can wait a bit longer.
